Message.Title: Cheap iPhone and China Mobile
Message.Msg: I live in China and of late have seen more and more mobile 4G units parked along busy traffic arteries during rush hour. They are all "China Mobile" trucks. It seems that, given the goal is to tap into the 650M China Mobile subscribers, three things would need to happen: 1. China Mobile needs 4G capability - Happening 2. The iPhone needs to be available at a lower price so the working people can afford it and still have an Apple product - Possible 3. Tim Cook and the China Mobile Chairman need to meet face to face - Happened Seems the planets may be aligning. I would be interested in thoughts from this board, as long as they are serious and constructive.

Message.Msg: My first question is ...Why spent your money either on speculation or as a hedge? You can accomplish both by selling a 6-13 month later dated options: call or call and put. Topic.Title: iPhone GM% Estimate for q1 2013

Message.Msg: I have seen iPhone gross margin estimates at between 38-58 percent. Take them with a grain of salt. Last quarter, Apple gross margins for the quarter were 40 percent they don't break it down by product. They projected lower gross margins for this quarter, "36 percent" because of the new launch of the mini and iPhone 5. Based on this, it is doubtful, that iPhone 5 margins will be higher then 4 or 4S. Your GM estimate of 39.4 percent seems a bit high but is roughly in the ballpark. The 52 million iPhones sold is what Sell Side analysts were projecting a couple of months ago but I am hearing that even they are saying that that number is too high. I have heard the 35M iphone number batted around. My models are suggesting a 12.50 EPS for the quarter based on those numbers.

Message.Msg: Given Apple's current valuation and its trailing P/E ratio under 12, the company is no longer priced for explosive growth. So the idea that Apple needs to grow at a 30 percent clip to be deemed a worthy investment by funds is absurd. Even if Apple's earnings growth slows to 20 percent this year or next, it would still be an outstanding buy with heathy upside even without any P/E expansion (which arguably there should be). Can you name one other company in the S&P 500 with an expected growth rate of 20 percent and a P/E ratio under 12... that also pays a dividend?

Message.Msg: While Yahoo! JAPAN faces competition in this division from Japanese eCommerce giant Rakuten, we think that the firm will be able to capitalize on the increase in online spending by consumers. [2] This growth will translate to an increase in the transaction value on both Yahoo! Auctions and Shopping, making this segment an important driver of Yahoo! JAPAN's value. Categories covered by CR are ease of use, messaging, browsing, display quality etc show that there are many options other than Iphone 5, and camera quality and batttery life also great on other phones than the Iphone 5. Motorola as well as being a top ranked phone has double the talk time battery life. Careful shoppers will not follow the herd to apple and this should show plenty of reasons for the recent correction in share price for taking a bite out of apples share price.

Message.Title: shocker move back up
Message.Msg: the more i study all sides of this arguement the more convinced i am of AAPL going back above $600, there just isnt enough reason to bring it down further. techincally we do have a bottle neck where its being held down and the trend line is resistance and the 50ema is resistance. But $500 is support and its held strong, volume is drying up. bad earnings are more then priced in, great earnings reverses the ternd. the company would have to fail miserably to fall below $500, we know that wont happen. When the company misses earnings twice, you can bet they come back with a vengence. This conpany is the standard, not the laggard. CNBC and most other guests are bashing shares loose but notice they wont let it go below $500? with all the talk of sub $500 as low as $350, it hasnt come close to closing below $500. You really think fund managers will just abandon this stock? Aint gonna happen. some one on the other board showed all the PUT verse CALL activity for Feb, if max pain or wiping out all the most contracts is in play for Feb, then we can expect a stock price above $600, as their are way more PUTs wanting this below $600 then there are CALLs wanting this above $500, thats alot of PUTs sold that can get wiped clean within weeks. my trade is in and im not changing it for anybody. I remember before Christmas watching CNBC hearing all the doom and gloom, i bought CALLs at $505 and the stock rocketd back near $540, then it fell again to $510, i bought CALLS again, it rocketed to $555, funny i had $555 calls, all the way CNBC bashed and bashed. Im describing to my girfriend what the entire market was saying about AAPL, she responded with "then why did you buy it"? I said "because im smarter then to believe what they are saying" it wasnt fun, but it was profitable ! I think thats the stance im taking here, my long position may not be fun. but its going to be profitable. I can just see it now. $625 after earnings and CNBC and FastMoney all cheering AAPL on, "after the fact" In this game, you gotta be able to think for yourself. or get fed into a meat grinder daily.

Message.Title: Apple TV, The Final Countdown
Message.Msg: Television is coming back to be a significant part of our life again. But this time, as an active participant. Just as the iPad sat on a shelf until everything was ready to fall in place, Apple has been getting ready for this for years. It's just been waiting for all the components to be flight-tested, fall in the right pricing range and be ready to go: - AppleTV, "the hobby" - Siri, "the beta" - Reasonably priced screens - and a slew of data-centers. It's only a question of time before all systems are ready for launch. And, the countdown has started. As Steve Jobs would say "Microsoft (MSFT) (and Google (GOOG) and Samsung (SSNLF.PK) ) _ start your photocopiers!"

That gets you to about a 100 percent increase in production of iPads and iPhones vs the previous quarter which gets you to 54 m phones and 30m iPads or some mix between them. Rumors are a 60m production rate which is possible, I am guessing apple shipped phones straight to customers from Taiwan and shipped what they produced and counted as venues probably right up to the last day. Wy they would sell only 80 percent of what they produced and be sitting on a warehouse of iPhones is hard to believe, if they had such a secret warehouse, I am guessing analysts would be using X-ray technology to figure out how much was in it.

Also, don't forget (as I just mentioned in another post), a large percent (maybe 40% or 50%) of iphones sold this past quarter were the 4 and the 4S. A study in the U.S. showed 32% of iPhones sold in October were the 4 and 4S and we know the 5 wasn't available in China and many other markets until very late in the quarter. I think they are going to strongly beat estimates, but I think it will be because of more 4 and 4S sales than people ever thought. Even with the discounts, the 4 and 4S probably carry higher margins by 5% to 7%. The combination of higher volume to spread costs against and higher sales of the 4 and 4S at higher margins should also assure a strong margin/EPS beat as well (if my assumptions are right).

Topic.Title: Apple TV, The Final Countdown

Message.Msg: I will pay a premium price for an AppleTV. Contrary to bashers' beliefs, Apple fans don't get Apple products only to "show off" to friends. There is that side effect, of course, but it is far from the whole story. As a matter of fact, if, when I purchase my next phone, there were some new law that I have to use the same nondescript case as everyone else and that I could not "show off" the screen while using it, I would still buy an iPhone. I appreciate the elegant simplicity of its use and the way it integrates into the rest of my life (computer, tablet, music, video, apps, etc)... even when nobody is watching. Most of the Apple fanboys - and there are over a hundred million worldwide - feel the same way. All of these bashers and analysts who say Apple is losing its edge are not in the set of fanboys. Therefore they don't understand what it would REALLY take to pry the Apple devices from the fanboys hands. They point to competition and the advances that are continuously being made as the black swan that can suddenly doom Apple. But if what they are talking about is a sexy new form factor or some "advanced" feature such as a larger screen or faster processor, that won't cut it for THIS fanboy, and every other one that I know. Somebody is going to have to come out with a COMPLETE product and ecosystem that either equals or exceeds the Apple solution. And such things don't just appear. They evolve from humble beginnings, just like iPod, iTunes, etc. Until that day, I will pay the Apple premium for the real deal. The bottom line is this: if you are a person that does not "bond" with a certain product (such as Apple's products, but not limited to just them) because you don't understand what others see in them to begin with, then how can you possibly understand what it would take to tear that bond? Such people's opinions usually involve belittling the bond as something less real, reasonable, or lasting. Their predictions are commensurate with their understanding, which is to say, "lacking". For instance, in one Kass article recently, he literally wrote that he didn't understand the allure of Apple products. Then in the next sentence he declared that the allure would soon fade. Left unstated was his additional assumption that the allure must be baseless and fleeting. (Since he doesn't understand it, how could it possibly be anything of value? This is his reasoning.) How wrong he is. The same thing will happen if and when Apple comes out with a TV set. People that have disposable income will line up to get it. I know I will. Thompson

Message.Title: Apple CEO Tim Cook ".I believe strongly that it will." that's all you need
Message.Msg: Apple CEO Tim Cook met with the chairman of China Mobile earlier this week to discuss the possibility of bringing the iPhone onto the nation's biggest network. Apple's sales in China more than doubled in 2010 and 2011, but China Mobile's 700 million subscribers remain largely out of reach. Following his meeting with the China Mobile exec, Cook was quoted by Xinhua as saying: " China is currently our second largest market. I believe it will become our first. I believe strongly that it will. [...] We are continuing to invest in retail stores here and will open many more over the next several years. We have some great sites selected, our manufacturing base is here, and we have incredible partners here. So it's a very very important country to us." The iPhone is definitely a sought-after brand in China, and Cook's comments reveal that the country will play a key role in Apple's future. This was the CEO's second trip to China in the past year, and if a China Mobile partnership works out, there will surely be many more trips coming.

Message.Title: Liquid-Crystal-Display Panel Makers Cut Output for iPhone 5 -Nikkei
Message.Msg: TOKYO--Japan Display Inc. and Sharp Corp. (6753.TO, SHCAY) have started reducing production of smartphone liquid-crystal-display panels for Apple Inc. (AAPL) amid slower-than-anticipated global sales of the iPhone 5., the Nikkei reports in its Jan. 14 edition. Japan Display, Sharp and South Korean concern LG Display Co. (034220.SE, LPL) supply LCD panels for the iPhone 5, which made its debut last September. Apple had planned to order from the trio enough panels for a total of 65 million units this quarter. But now, the U.S. company is believed to have notified them about roughly halving that figure. Japan Display, which operates six plants in Japan, is expected to feel the biggest impact. A plant in Nomi, Ishikawa Prefecture--a dedicated facility in which Apple invested heavily and that began operating last June--is expected to temporarily reduce output by 70% to 80% compared with the October-December term. Another Ishikawa plant that handles output for the iPhone 5 will shift to production for other clients, but the transition could take a few months. Apple's cutbacks could deal Japan Display's sales a direct blow for the time being. Sharp's Kameyama No. 1 plant in Mie Prefecture, a dedicated facility for iPhone 5 LCD panels, will slash output in January and February by around 40% from the October-December quarter, when it was near full capacity. The Kameyama No. 2 plant, whose customers for small and midsize panels extend beyond Apple, will cultivate demand for use in notebook computers to help pick up the slack. Seiko Epson Corp. (6724.TO, SEKEY), Murata Manufacturing Co. (6981.TO) and TDK Corp. (6762.TO, TTDKY) manufacture electronic parts for the iPhone 5. "Since this month, iPhone-related orders have shrunken by half," a senior executive at a parts maker says.

We didn't hit the bottom of the channel, but there's nothing that says the stock has to follow the playbook exactly, maybe it will, but I'm not risking a wait and see play at this point, It's like playing a game of chicken with what I expect will be a best ever quarter. It's the perfect set up, correction has us in the channel, phone sales are great, the year ago quarter reflects Christmas shopping, subsequent quarters pulled back no doubt because customers were waiting for next gen. Well here are waitng for the Christmas quarter numbers, next gen is out, and a host of new markets are open to AAPL products. Couple that with everyone loved AAPL at 700, and if fell, now everyone hates it at 500... Time to get on board, the train is pulling out of the station. It couldn't be more obvious if someone hit you in the head with an I-brick.

Topic.Title: How can you know if any stock is prey to naked short selling?

Message.Msg: Great question: And you are right. The SEC has a lot of trouble tracking it. They basically made it illegal in 2008. Read: It is difficult to measure how often naked short selling occurs. Fails to deliver are not necessarily indicative of naked shorting, and can result from both "long" transactions (stock purchases) and short sales. Naked shorting can be invisible in a liquid market, as long as the short sale is eventually delivered to the buyer. However, if the covers are impossible to find, the trades fail. Fail reports are published regularly by the SEC, and a sudden rise in the number of fails-to-deliver will alert the SEC to the possibility of naked short selling. In some recent cases, it was claimed that the daily activity was larger than all of the available shares, which would normally be unlikely. Note: those who are unable to deliver (like Lehman) get into a whole lot of trouble....

Message.Msg: Yes I saw some Wall Street models as low as 27 or 28m iPhones actually produced in January. Last year Foxconn was down about 15 percent sequentially from December to January and then another 15 percent from January to February. Cmponent suppliers have even more fluctuations. This is peculiar to Apple because they have the big launches. Most others have a very weak fourth quarter as production ramps in the third. Production and inventory build is quite different from sell through. First quarter sales for apple is always down after the launch usually about 15 to 20 percent. Hope all that helps.

Message.Msg: It's all done by the large brokerage houses. They can hide it. If an individual shorts, they can only short to the max of margin. If the price rises, they get called away. Different for the large brokers. The complexity of their dealings prevents the SEC from seeing the true facts.

Message.Title: China Mobile: Under Confidential Agreement Already
Message.Msg: Read this a few times, especially the last paragraph, and don't discuss it with the short gumps. BTW, most of the Asians with smartphones are not on monthly plans; rather, they buy the minutes they need. That is a big part of why CMobile wanted a better deal than "FY" from AAPL, and it will be interesting to see what if anything AAPL gave them to ink the deal likely to be announced at any minute. What really matters to Asians is having the best smartphone they can get, and there is no bigger status symbol for aspirational Asians than the iPhone. What really matters to AAPL and the stock is getting going on an even footing to all Asian consumers willing to spend a month's wages to buy an iPhone and Mini Ipad. Shorts will be torched when this is announced -- likely, it seems, between now and December 23. January 11, 2013 China Mobile Admits to a Confidentiality Agreement with Apple Yesterday we reported that Apple would be tripling their Apple Stores in China. The other news is that Apple met with Mobile China that we reported in December that Apple has been secretly working with them for four years now. The problem, as we reported, concerned China Mobile's upgrade to 4G networks. The transition to the new standard may now have been achieved as it appears that a formal deal may have been formalized between Apple and China Mobile. Taiwan News is reporting today that China Mobile released a statement saying that chairman Xi Guohua and Apple's CEO Tim Cook discussed "bilateral cooperation," and that the "release of other details was barred by a confidentiality agreement between the companies." Their framing of that statement indicates that a deal was struck. That's also likely why Cook said that China would become Apple's largest market on this same business trip. Securing a deal with Mobile China would definitely make China their number one market over the next year or two. Our December report showed that Mobile China would have a third of their market on 4G in the coming year which works out to a potential target of 233 million subscribers that Apple would be able to sell into. That's a market that's double the current US smartphone subscriber base.

Message.Title: AAPL: Conservative Guidance
Message.Msg: “Given our estimative for a 79% sequential unit increase in iPhone sales that represent Apple’s highest-margin hardware product line, we believe Apple’s December quarter gross margin guidance of 36% could prove conservative, and we are modeling 39.1%,” said Michael Walkley, tech analyst at Canaccord Genuity. He added, “Our December wireless store surveys indicated strong sales of the top-selling iPhone 5 at AT&T/Verizon/Sprint. Our surveys further indicated improved overall supply of the iPhone 5 with essentially all stores offering all SKUs of the iPhone 5. We believe the iPhone 5 was the top selling smartphone at AT&T/Sprint/Verizon and overall the best selling smartphone in the U.S. market.” Mr. Walkley lowered his 2013 EPS estimate to $50.25 from $51.95 based on slightly higher iPhone 4 sales in its revenue and reiterated his $750 price target.

Message.Title: China Export Surge Spurs Data Skepticism at Goldman, UBS By Bloomberg News - Jan 13, 2013 8:00 AM PT
Message.Msg: China’s unexpected surge in exports last month renewed concern from analysts at Goldman Sachs Group Inc., UBS AG and Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. (ANZ) that statistics from the nation can be unreliable. The 14.1 percent jump from a year earlier was the biggest positive surprise since March 2011, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The increase didn’t match goods movements through ports and imports by trading partners according to UBS, while Goldman Sachs and Mizuho Securities Asia Ltd. cited a divergence from overseas orders in a manufacturing index.

Message.Title: I used to love APPLE, but...
Message.Msg: NOT AS AN INVESTMENT HERE: History is littered with consumer electronics companies that have seen their stocks soar, only to come crashing down when technology changes or the company experiences an operation misstep. It not a question of if this will happen, but when. Some examples of the numerous companies include: - RCA or Radio Corporation of America, which fell 98% in the 1930s from its 1929 peak. - Polaroid and Eastman Kodak (EKDKQ.PK), tech icons from the 1970s, which went bankrupt in the past few years. - Sony (SNE), the 1980s and 1990s consumer electronics giant, whose stock is down 93 percent from its 2000 peak. - Nokia (NOK), the dominate maker of cell phones in the 1990s whose stock is down 94 percent from its 2000 peak.

Message.Title: How Apple Gets To $400 A Share?
Message.Msg: Stocks are valued based on the future, not the past, and there are challenges. Competition in the smartphone space is quickly increasing; Google (GOOG)'s Android platform is the market share leader, while former first movers Nokia (NOK) and Research in Motion (RIMM) are attempting turnarounds. Both Amazon and Google have attempted to undercut Apple's iPad in the tablet space. Lurking in the distance is Chinese giant Lenovo (LNVGY.PK), who plans to compete in the smartphone and US personal computer segments as both industries become more commoditized. Moreover, Apple is only ranked #6 in China. Where Samsung is swallowing market like no others. Google, Nokia, and Lenovo lead the China and it's only getting worse for Apple. Not only Apple will get to $400 a share soon, it may be trending down to the $300-250 range....

Topic.Title: APPLE TO BE DOWN BIG TOMORROW HALVED ITS NEED FOR LCD SCREENS

Message.Msg: no the article about sharp cutting iPhone 5 lcd displays is from todays nikkiei and names sharp not foxconn cutting orders in half at apples request. TOKYO--Japan Display Inc. and Sharp Corp. (6753.TO, SHCAY) have started reducing production of smartphone liquid-crystal-display panels for Apple Inc. AAPL -0.61% amid slower-than-anticipated global sales of the iPhone 5., the Nikkei reports in its Jan. 14 edition. Japan Display, Sharp and South Korean concern LG Display Co. (034220.SE, LPL) supply LCD panels for the iPhone 5, which made its debut last September. Apple had planned to order from the trio enough panels for a total of 65 million units this quarter. But now, the U.S. company is believed to have notified them about roughly halving that figure. Japan Display, which operates six plants in Japan, is expected to feel the biggest impact. A plant in Nomi, Ishikawa Prefecture--a dedicated facility in which Apple invested heavily and that began operating last June--is expected to temporarily reduce output by 70% to 80% compared with the October-December term. Another Ishikawa plant that handles output for the iPhone 5 will shift to production for other clients, but the transition could take a few months. Apple's cutbacks could deal Japan Display's sales a direct blow for the time being. Sharp's Kameyama No. 1 plant in Mie Prefecture, a dedicated facility for iPhone 5 LCD panels, will slash output in January and February by around 40% from the October-December quarter, when it was near full capacity. The Kameyama No. 2 plant, whose customers for small and midsize panels extend beyond Apple, will cultivate demand for use in notebook computers to help pick up the slack. Seiko Epson Corp. (6724.TO, SEKEY), Murata Manufacturing Co. (6981.TO) and TDK Corp. (6762.TO, TTDKY) manufacture electronic parts for the iPhone 5. "Since this month, iPhone-related orders have shrunken by half," a senior executive at a parts maker says.

Message.Title: WSJ: Apple Cuts Order for iPhone Parts on Weak Demand
Message.Msg: Apple Cuts Order for iPhone Parts on Weak Demand January 13, 2013, 8:51 p.m. ET By JURO OSAWA Apple Inc. AAPL -0.61% has cut its component orders for the iPhone 5 due to weaker-than-expected demand, people familiar with the situation said Monday. Apple's orders for screens for the January-March quarter, for example, have dropped to roughly half of what it had previously planned to order, two of the people said. The U.S. company has also cut orders for components other than screens, according to one of the people. Apple notified the suppliers of the order cut last month, they said. The move comes at a time when Apple faces greater competition from South Korea's Samsung Electronics Co. 005930.SE +0.13% and other makers of smartphones powered by Google Inc.'s GOOG -0.20% Android mobile operating system. Apple released the iPhone 5 in September. The latest model comes with a longer, 4-inch screen compared with the 3.5-inch screens used in all previous iPhone models. Apple representatives weren't immediately available for comment. Japan's Nikkei reported earlier Monday that Apple has slashed its orders for iPhone 5 components.

Topic.Title: LCD Order Cut on Weak Demand

Message.Msg: This is not bad news. What the Wall Street Journal cleverly left out of the original Marketwatch story was that Apple had plans for ordering 65 million LCD panels this quarter between 3 vendors. There is absolutely no way they were planning on selling that many iPhone 5s. What probably happened is that they put in large orders at each vendor in case one or two of the vendors were having problems making the screens. Recall that Sharp was having all sorts of problems before the launch. Now that there is no problem with yields they are dropping their orders to meet demand which appears to be about 35 million. Considering that the 4 and 4S are still big sellers this means Apple anticipates selling at least 50 million phones this quarter.

Topic.Title: Samsung Galaxy Note II

Message.Msg: Hate to say I told you so: Shares in LG Display, a supplier for Apple Inc. , tumbled to their lowest levels in nearly three months, after a media report said its Japanese peers cut panel output for the iPhone 5. The report by Nikkei fuelled market talks that Apple has slashed component orders because of slower-than-expected sales of its latest iPhone. Analysts have also downgraded their earnings estimates for the current quarter, citing possible order cuts. LG Display has lost more than 7 percent this month, after a 10 percent slump in December.

Message.Title: "Going Concern" Sharp Shutting Down Plants And Winding Down Due To Uncertain Future iPhone Orders
Message.Msg: TOKYO--Japan Display Inc. and Sharp Corp. (6753.TO, SHCAY) have started reducing production of smartphone liquid-crystal-display panels for Apple Inc. AAPL -0.61% amid slower-than-anticipated global sales of the iPhone 5., the Nikkei reports in its Jan. 14 edition. Japan Display, Sharp and South Korean concern LG Display Co. (034220.SE, LPL) supply LCD panels for the iPhone 5, which made its debut last September. Apple had planned to order from the trio enough panels for a total of 65 million units this quarter. But now, the U.S. company is believed to have notified them about roughly halving that figure. Japan Display, which operates six plants in Japan, is expected to feel the biggest impact. A plant in Nomi, Ishikawa Prefecture--a dedicated facility in which Apple invested heavily and that began operating last June--is expected to temporarily reduce output by 70% to 80% compared with the October-December term. Another Ishikawa plant that handles output for the iPhone 5 will shift to production for other clients, but the transition could take a few months. Apple's cutbacks could deal Japan Display's sales a direct blow for the time being. Sharp's Kameyama No. 1 plant in Mie Prefecture, a dedicated facility for iPhone 5 LCD panels, will slash output in January and February by around 40% from the October-December quarter, when it was near full capacity. The Kameyama No. 2 plant, whose customers for small and midsize panels extend beyond Apple, will cultivate demand for use in notebook computers to help pick up the slack. Seiko Epson Corp. (6724.TO, SEKEY), Murata Manufacturing Co. (6981.TO) and TDK Corp. (6762.TO, TTDKY) manufacture electronic parts for the iPhone 5. "Since this month, iPhone-related orders have shrunken by half," a senior executive at a parts maker says.

Message.Title: SHARPS SAYS BATTERY LIFE IS 300 % MORE IN SMARTPHONES WITH IGZO.
Message.Msg: IGZO is a backplane technology describing the materials used for the thin film transistors that drive the display. The tech requires less LEDs for backlighting leading to a huge improvement in power draw and therefore, battery life. So much so, that Sharp says mobile devices could have up to 300 percent better battery life, a number that cannot be ignored. For example, Sharp's own Aquos Phone has a 2,320mAh battery and the company says it should last a full 48 hours on a single charge with "normal usage." Most current smartphones (with the exception of the Motorola Maxx line), including the iPhone and Samsung Galaxy S III average 18-24 hours for "normal" usage on a single charge. OR THEY COULD MAKE A SMALLER BATTERY AND THINNER DEVICES WITH A 150 % INCREASE. JUST SAYING

Message.Title: Original order was for 65M
Message.Msg: This iPhone cut story is a complete non-story. Apple apparently ordered 65M screens total from 3 different vendors. Clearly they did not intend to sell that many iPhone 5s. It seems safe to assume they placed unusually large order plans in order to account for the possibility that one vendor might not be able to make enough screens. Sharp was reported to be having difficult before the launch so over ordering not only makes sense but was the smart thing to do. Now that yields are not a problem Apple seems to be cutting orders to meet demand. Considering that they are now ordering 35M screens and probably over ordered last quarter is seems safe to assume Apple is expecting to sell at least 40M iPhone 5s this quarter. Combined with the iPhone 4 and 4S that means Apple is expecting to sell over well over 50M phones next quarter.

Message.Title: It's Quit Simple.
Message.Msg: You need to ask yourselves this one simple question, if every major fund and manager had this on their books, and there has been nothing but bad press, true or not, who do you expect to pick up all the slack? This is the major downside to playing in a stock that was soo grossly over-booked by the funds. They were making and showing huge returns just by sitting with this over the last few years. Unfortunately, just to maintain a base price you need to have some institution that is willing to support the Distribution, and right now you don't. Forget all of the stories and the lines in the I-Phone stores you have seen in the past, it means absolutely nothing. The ONLY thing that matter in this game is Accumulation vs. Distribution and being on the right side of it. And right now the money to be made is on the Distribution side. It wouldn't matter if they resurrected Steve Jobs, this thing will continue to bleed out until the "Street" settles the bid, and you won't see that until we see capitulation, ie: a good 40-60 point down day, which might come sooner than later. Oh, and here's a fact that didn't exist when Apple began it's run over the last 3 years, Google now has a far superior product line. Apple is becoming more and more the kids phone. You are better off going after RIMM if you are seeking quality at a reduce premium to market. Best of luck to all, as tomorrow appears to be shaping up to be an ugly day for AAPL

Message.Msg: I think the surprise will be iPhone 4 and 4S demand. iPhone 5 sales are fine. We know it from all the data we have so far. Market growth is fine (40% according to ICD). Topic.Title: The order cuts are due to a new form factor for iphone 6 #$%$ Shorts & WSJ

Message.Msg: Apple Inc. has started testing a new iPhone and the next version of its iOS software, news website reported. Application developers have found in their app usage logs references to a new iPhone identifier, iPhone 6.1, running iOS 7 operating system, the website reported. Apple's iPhone 5 bears the identifiers "iPhone 5.1" and "iPhone 5.2" and is powered by iOS 6 operating system. Developer logs show that the app requests originate from an internet address on Apple's Cupertino campus, suggesting that Apple engineers are testing compatibility for some of the popular apps, the website said. "Although OS and device data can be faked, the unique IP footprint leading back to Apple's Cupertino campus leads us to believe this is not one of those attempts," the website said. Apple launched iPhone 5 in September and it has been reported that the new iPhone will be released in the middle of 2013.

Message.Title: READ ABOUT SUPPLY CUTS ON THE 4S - 11/2011
Message.Msg: Excerpt from the article followed by full article: "What’s interesting is that comparable reports appeared in the past as well and the experts considered that Apple has a habit of pre-ordering a large amount of components in order to make sure that they have sufficient devices available in case the demand is very high. After they estimate the realistic sales they obviously need to cut back on the orders. Until now nobody knows if this is the same case, or people just don’t buy as many Apple products as they expected." Apple Cuts Down iPhone 4S Orders Due To Weak Demand By Marius MariaNovember 10, 2011CellPhones Apple had a real sales boom when they launched the new iPhone 4S as they manage to sell more than 4 million devices only in the opening weekend which is pretty incredible. Furthermore, the Apple officials stated that more and more customers are using their new operating system meaning iOS 5, and it’s the same story with iCloud. Excited about these numbers, Apple decided that the iPhone 4S should be launched in over 90 different countries thinking that they would have the same results. The newest report shows otherwise and the company is anticipating a sale slowdown in the fourth quarter of 2011. A new report appeared on DigiTimes says that Apple has cut a major amount of orders with the component suppliers. The sources of the report are not clear yet, but they claim that Apple will no longer produce as many smartphones as before. It looks like Apple had great sale expectations in many countries, but the numbers show a lower demand in the fourth quarter of 2011 and in the first quarter of 2012. Therefore, Apple doesn’t need all the components which they first ordered and have to renounce them. What’s interesting is that comparable reports appeared in the past as well and the experts considered that Apple has a habit of pre-ordering a large amount of components in order to make sure that they have sufficient devices available in case the demand is very high. After they estimate the realistic sales they obviously need to cut back on the orders. Until now nobody knows if this is the same case, or people just don’t buy as many Apple products as they expected. Some of the analysts estimate that over 4o millions iPhones could be shipped by Apple in the last months of 2011. Surely the iPhone 4S is one big reason why the demand seems to be so strong. However, Apple expected a lot more of the iPhone 4S to be sold and that’s probably why the components orders have been decreased, because the device is not meeting their high expectations. Consequently, the numbers that the analysts estimated appear to be more and more improbable. And if we take in consideration the sales that Apple had in the past which never exceeded 17 million devices, the 40 million iPhones sold in a quarter remains just a dream for Apple.

Message.Title: Article on iPhone screens
Message.Msg: Analyst: Apple’s Display Future Looks Like This By Aabha Rathee | More Articles January 08, 2013 Topeka Capital analyst Brian White Sharp has said it’s inevitable for Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) to start using Sharp’s new IGZO technology, which was showed off by the manufacturer at the Consumer Electronics Show as the future of mobile displays. Sharp said the advanced displays had twice the resolution of a conventional LCD screen with up to 90 percent power savings. They can also continue to display an image when the power is turned off. Should you buy or sell Apple’s stock ahead of earnings this month? Our 20-page proprietary analysis will help you save time and make money. Click here to get your SPECIAL REPORT now. The buzz about Apple possibly buying the new screens has been swirling for a while, with word a few months ago that it was investigating using the panels in the third-generation iPad. That, according to some reports, didn’t happen because the technology was not ready for mass production. Sharp was accompanied at the IGZO demonstration by Apple mobile display supplier Corning (NYSE:GLW). White, who attended the demonstration, wrote in a research note after the event that Apple would be the “prime candidate” to adopt IGZO for its mobile devices. While using it would help Apple compete more strongly with Samsung (SSNLF.PK), such a deal with Sharp would also reduce its reliance on LG Display (NYSE:LPL), he said. The Apple display manufacturer had struggled to meet the required standards and quantities for the iPad’s Retina display in early 2012.

Message.Msg: Something really stinks bad in this story. The article specifically implies that Apple had ordered 60+ million displays for the quarter ending March 31. But that would mean they expected to sell more 5's in the quarter following the Christmas quarter ending Dec. 31, Apple's most profitable quarter of the year!! When has Apple's fiscal year second quarter EVER outsold their fiscal first quarter? I think that "The Nikkei" was really reporting a decrease of production from first fiscal quarter of about 60 million displays to 30-40 million displays in the second quarter, just the same old ramping down that occurs every year. I think Reuters, WSJ, and DigiTimes ALL know this, but disregard it so that they can be the first to report the gloom and doom (albeit unverified) "news" about AAPL. we'll see sometime tomorrow morning.

Topic.Title: READ ABOUT SUPPLY CUTS ON THE 4S - 11/2011

Message.Msg: Back in August, amidst Apple's frenzied Summer run-up, Paulo Santos made an interesting observation. Apple's Summer surge happened while an enormous amount of long options were being written. The surge in Apple's share price looked to have started in the options market and carried over to the common stock as long option writers covered their bets: The first option of a new year generally has more interest than other dates and that is the case here - the huge open interest in Apple is most especially heavy in the January 19, 2013 expiring options. Most of that is call options in the $550-$800 strike range. There are hundreds of thousands:
